nodes.bodyText: typo? put put?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,42 +2,31 @@
 Add data to caches with the {brandname} CLI.
 
 .Prerequisites
-* Create a cache named "mycache".
+* Create a cache named "mycache" and `cd` into it.
++
+[source,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+[//containers/default]> cd caches/mycache
+----
 
 .Procedure
-. Add a key/value pair to `mycache`.
+. Put an entry into "mycache".
 +
 [source,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
 ----
-[//containers/default]> put --cache=mycache hello world
+[//containers/default/caches/mycache]> put put hello world

nodes.bodyText: suggestion: Passivated <N> entries in <M> milliseconds
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,38 +1,38 @@
 = Shutting Down {brandname} Servers
 Use the CLI to gracefully shutdown running servers. This ensures that {brandname} passivates all entries to disk and persists state.
 
-* Use the `shutdown server` command to stop individual servers, for example:
+* Use the `shutdown server` command to stop individual servers.
 +
 [source,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
 ----
-[//containers/default]> shutdown server server_hostname
+[//containers/default]> shutdown server $hostname
 ----
 
-* Use the `shutdown cluster` command to stop all servers joined to the cluster, for example:
+* Use the `shutdown cluster` command to stop all servers joined to the cluster.
 +
 [source,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
 ----
 [//containers/default]> shutdown cluster
 ----
 
-{brandname} servers log the following shutdown messages:
+.Verification
+
+Check the server logs for the following messages:
 
 [source,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
 ----
-INFO  [org.infinispan.SERVER] (pool-3-thread-1) ISPN080002: Infinispan Server stopping
-INFO  [org.infinispan.CONTAINER] (pool-3-thread-1) ISPN000029: Passivating all entries to disk
-INFO  [org.infinispan.CONTAINER] (pool-3-thread-1) ISPN000030: Passivated 28 entries in 46 milliseconds
-INFO  [org.infinispan.CLUSTER] (pool-3-thread-1) ISPN000080: Disconnecting JGroups channel cluster
-INFO  [org.infinispan.CONTAINER] (pool-3-thread-1) ISPN000390: Persisted state, version=<{brandname} version> timestamp=YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS
-INFO  [org.infinispan.SERVER] (pool-3-thread-1) ISPN080003: Infinispan Server stopped
-INFO  [org.infinispan.SERVER] (Thread-0) ISPN080002: Infinispan Server stopping
-INFO  [org.infinispan.SERVER] (Thread-0) ISPN080003: Infinispan Server stopped
+ISPN080002: Infinispan Server stopping
+ISPN000029: Passivating all entries to disk
+ISPN000030: Passivated 28 entries in 46 milliseconds

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -216,24 +216,25 @@ If you plan to store entries in the cache as custom Java objects or POJOs, you m
 
 To make entity classes available to the server, do the following:
 
-* Create a `JAR` file that contains the entities and dependencies.
-* Stop {brandname} if it is running.
+. Create a JAR file that contains the entities and dependencies.
+. Stop {brandname} if it is running. {brandname} only loads entity classes at
+boot time.
+. Copy the JAR to the `server/lib` directory of your {brandname} server installation.
 +
-{brandname} loads entity classes during boot. You cannot make entity classes available to {brandname} if the server is running.
+----
+├── server
+│   ├── lib
+│       ├── deployment.my-entities.jar
+----
++
+. Specify the `JAR` file as a module in the Cache Manager configuration.

nodes.bodyText: The second sentence is no longer valid. @wburns fixed it with the non-blocking work.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -199,7 +193,7 @@ These are, in order of cost:
 * writing to a cache store (optional)
 * locking
 
-As of {brandname} 4.0, using the async methods will take the network calls and marshalling off the critical path.  For various technical reasons, writing to a cache store and acquiring locks, however, still happens in the caller's thread.  In future, we plan to take these offline as well.  See link:http://lists.jboss.org/pipermail/infinispan-dev/2010-January/002219.html[this developer mail list thread] about this topic.
+Using the async methods will take the network calls and marshalling off the critical path.  For various technical reasons, writing to a cache store and acquiring locks, however, still happens in the caller's thread.

nodes.bodyText: removed the 2nd sentence. thanks @pruivo
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -199,7 +193,7 @@ These are, in order of cost:
 * writing to a cache store (optional)
 * locking
 
-As of {brandname} 4.0, using the async methods will take the network calls and marshalling off the critical path.  For various technical reasons, writing to a cache store and acquiring locks, however, still happens in the caller's thread.  In future, we plan to take these offline as well.  See link:http://lists.jboss.org/pipermail/infinispan-dev/2010-January/002219.html[this developer mail list thread] about this topic.
+Using the async methods will take the network calls and marshalling off the critical path.  For various technical reasons, writing to a cache store and acquiring locks, however, still happens in the caller's thread.

nodes.bodyText: is there new docs for scripts? or it is no longer supported?

@pruivo yes, this is an old doc that was in the Server Guide and has been replaced. I forgot to remove it when I made those changes. see: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/infinispan/infinispan/master/documentation/src/main/asciidoc/stories/assembly_server_scripts.adoc
well, technically, you can't create, configure or manage cache via Cache. That would be the CacheManager.

-= The Cache API
+= Cache API
 
-== The Cache interface
-{brandname}'s Caches are manipulated through the link:{javadocroot}/org/infinispan/Cache.html[Cache] interface.
+== Cache interface
+{brandname} provides a link:{javadocroot}/org/infinispan/Cache.html[Cache]
+interface for creating, configuring, and managing Caches.

nodes.bodyText:
this can be removed IMO.
They are deprecated in 10: @deprecated Since 10.0, custom interceptors support will be removed and only modules will be able to define interceptors
If you don't want to remove them, just put a warning saying it will be removed... soon... :)
